definition: Liu Bowen (1311-1375), general under the first Ming emperor Zhu Yuanzhang 朱元璋, with a reputation as a military genius/also called Liu Ji 劉基|刘基
(classical) a type of battle-ax/to kill/to slaughter
surname Liu
father's elder brother/senior/paternal elder uncle/eldest of brothers/respectful form of address/Count, third of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]
one hundred (old)
variant of 霸[ba4]
warm/lukewarm/temperature/to warm up/mild/soft/tender/to review (a lesson etc)/fever (TCM)/old variant of 瘟[wen1]
surname Wen

sentences.chinese: 刘伯温就是在这儿出生的。

sentences.english: Do you know who is Liu Bowen?
Chu's close advisor, Liu Po-wen, finally came up with a brilliant idea.
sentences.chinese: 他的贴身智囊刘伯温最终想出了一个绝妙的点子。

definition: Liu Ji or Liu Bowen 劉伯溫|刘伯温 (1311-1375), general under the first Ming emperor Zhu Yuanzhang 朱元璋, with a reputation as a military genius
Zhu Yuanzhang, personal name of first Ming dynasty emperor Hongwu 洪武[Hong2 wu3]
reign name of second Ming emperor, reigned 1398-1402, deposed in 1402
Ming Taizu, Temple name of first Ming emperor Hongwu 洪武[Hong2 wu3]
Zhu Di, personal name of third Ming Emperor Yongle 永樂|永乐[Yong3 le4]
Zhao Kuangyin, personal name of founding Song emperor Song Taizu 宋太祖 (927-976)
Xiao He (-193 BC), famous strategist and chancellor, fought on Liu Bang's 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1] side during the Chu-Han Contention 楚漢戰爭|楚汉战争[Chu3 Han4 Zhan4 zheng1]
Emperor Taizu of Song, posthumous title of the founding Song emperor Zhao Kuangyin 趙匡胤|赵匡胤 (927-976), reigned from 960
Wang Qinruo (962-1025), Northern Song dynasty official
Liu Bang (256 or 247-195 BC), bandit leader who became first Han emperor Han Gaozu 漢高祖|汉高祖 (reigned 202-195 BC)
Song Lian (1310-1381), Ming dynasty writer, historian and politician
Fan Li (536-488 BC), politician of Yue state, businessman and economist
Li Zicheng (1605-1645), leader of peasant rebellion at the end of the Ming Dynasty

Zhuge Liang (181-234), military leader and prime minister of Shu Han 蜀漢|蜀汉 during the Three Kingdoms period/the main hero of the fictional Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义, where he is portrayed as a sage and military genius/mastermind
Zeng Guofan (1811-1872), Qing dynasty politician and military man
Zhang Juzheng (1525-1582), Grand Secretary during the Ming dynasty, credited with bringing the dynasty to its apogee
